Federal Court
Lutfy, C.J.
February 25, 2005.
Counsel:
Ahlam J. Balazs, for the applicant;
Robert Drummond, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Ahlam J. Balazx, for the applicant;
John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Ottawa, Ontario, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Lutfy, C.J.
: The Pinter family, the spouses and their three young children, are failed refugee claimants. They are citizens of Hungary. Mrs. Pinter is of Roma descent. The family's refugee claim was based on the fear of persecution resulting from their Roma ethnicity.

[2]
In explaining her rationale for her refusal of the Pinters' request for permanent residence within Canada, the immigration officer noted:
"I have not dealt with the risk factors of the applications since they were reviewed by the Pre-Removal Risk Assessment officer who determined the family would not be at risk if they were returned to Hungary. The risk identified in the Humanitarian and Compassionate application is identical to the risk identified in the PRRA application."
Contrary to the immigration officer's suggestion, there is a difference between the assessment of risk factors in an application for humanitarian and compassionate consideration and one for protection from removal.

[3]
In an application for humanitarian and compassionate consideration under section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), the applicant's burden is to satisfy the decision-maker that there would be unusual and undeserved or disproportionate hardship to obtain a permanent resident visa from outside Canada.

[4]
In a pre-removal risk assessment under sections 97, 112 and 113 of the IRPA, protection may be afforded to a person who, upon removal from Canada to their country of nationality, would be subject to a risk to their life or to a risk of cruel and unusual treatment.

[5]
In my view, it was an error in law for the immigration officer to have concluded that she was not required to deal with risk factors in her assessment of the humanitarian and compassionate application. She should not have closed her mind to risk factors even though a valid negative pre-removal risk assessment may have been made. There may well be risk considerations which are relevant to an application for permanent residence from within Canada which fall well below the higher threshold of risk to life or cruel and unusual punishment.

[6]
By stating that the risk identified in one is identical to the risk identified in the other, the immigration officer could not have had an open mind to all considerations that she had to take into account in making a proper evaluation of an application under section 25 of the IRPA.

[7]
It is on the basis of this error in law that the applicants' application for judicial review will be granted. Concerning the other grounds raised by the applicants, I should make only one comment. The immigration officer noted the applicants' involvement in the Edmonton community with Canadians of Hungarian ethnic origin. She added that no evidence was presented "of community involvement outside their ethnic background." The intended purpose of this statement is not apparent.

[8]
As they requested at the hearing, the parties may submit a serious question for certification within seven (7) days of the date of these reasons for order.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) section 25
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) sections 97, 112 and 113
legal_issues: The proper assessment of risk factors when considering applications for permanent residence based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds versus pre-removal risk assessments.
Whether a prior negative pre-removal risk assessment precludes the consideration of risk factors in a subsequent application for permanent residence.
The standard of evidence required to demonstrate community involvement in the context of immigration applications.
The scope of discretion afforded to immigration officers in evaluating applications for permanent residence.
factual_background: A family (the Pinters) consisting of a couple and three children are citizens of Hungary.
The wife is of Roma descent.
The family previously applied for refugee status, which was denied.
The family subsequently applied for permanent residence in Canada based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds.
The application for permanent residence was refused by an immigration officer.
The immigration officer referenced a previous negative pre-removal risk assessment (PRRA) in their decision.
The immigration officer noted the family's involvement with the Hungarian community in Edmonton but stated no evidence of involvement outside of that community was presented.
The family's claim for permanent residence was based on a fear of persecution due to their Roma ethnicity.

Applicants: The immigration officer erred in law by refusing to assess risk factors in the humanitarian and compassionate application.

The immigration officer incorrectly equated the risk assessment required for a Humanitarian and Compassionate consideration (section 25 IRPA) with that of a Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (sections 97, 112, 113 IRPA).
The immigration officer’s statement regarding a lack of community involvement outside their ethnic background was inappropriate and its purpose was unclear.
Respondents: The Pre-Removal Risk Assessment officer determined the family would not be at risk if returned to Hungary.
The risk identified in the Humanitarian and Compassionate application was identical to the risk identified in the PRRA application (as stated by the immigration officer).

court_analysis: The court found that the immigration officer erred in law by refusing to independently assess the risk factors relevant to the Pinter family’s humanitarian and compassionate application for permanent residence, relying instead on a prior negative pre-removal risk assessment (PRRA).

The court distinguished between the legal standards for a PRRA and a humanitarian and compassionate application under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). A PRRA requires a showing of risk to life or cruel and unusual treatment, while a humanitarian and compassionate application requires assessing unusual and undeserved hardship, which can be triggered by lower levels of risk.

The court reasoned that even a valid negative PRRA does not preclude the need to consider risk factors in a section 25 IRPA application, as risks relevant to one application may not meet the higher threshold required for the other.

The court determined that the immigration officer’s statement equating the risk identified in both applications demonstrated a closed mind to relevant considerations required for a proper evaluation under section 25 of the IRPA.
Because of this error in law, the court granted the application for judicial review, finding that the immigration officer’s decision was flawed in its legal reasoning.
final_outcome: Parties may submit a serious question for certification within seven days.
